home.Title: Anestix
home.PlatformDescription: Your comprehensive platform for anesthesiology professionals

comprehensive_resources.title: Comprehensive Resources
comprehensive_resources.description: Access a wide range of anesthesiology resources, clinical guidelines, and research papers.

calculators_for_scales.title: Calculators for Scales
calculators_for_scales.description: Utilize built-in calculators for common anesthesiology scales, risk assessments, dosage calculations, and more to support informed clinical decision-making.

continuous_learning.title: Continuous Learning
continuous_learning.description: Stay updated with the latest in anesthesiology practices, certifications, and continuing medical education opportunities.

dashboard.no_items: There are no items available right now

scale-list.title: Scales
scale-list.description: Empower your clinical decisions with our comprehensive range of medical scales, including RASS, FOUR, Glasgow, and more. Each section provides detailed scoring guides.

calculators.title: Calculators
calculators.description: Utilize our precision tools to compute drug dosages and other vital parameters. Each calculator comes with in-depth guides and safety tips to ensure accurate, patient-specific outcomes..

ultrasound.title: Ultrasound
ultrasound.description: Here you'll find detailed protocols and guidelines for ultrasound-assisted procedures, including nerve block visualization.

skills.title: Skills
skills.description: Dive into in‑depth information on medical procedures and practical skills across many sub‑sections.

rass.title: RASS
rass.description: Assesses sedation and agitation levels in critically ill patients to guide sedation management.

four.title: FOUR
four.description: Evaluates consciousness with a focus on brainstem reflexes and respiratory patterns for a detailed neurological assessment.

gcs.title: GCS
gcs.description: Measures the level of consciousness following head injuries or neurological impairments.

alderte.title: Aldrete
alderte.description: Determines a patient's readiness for discharge from post-anesthesia recovery by assessing activity, respiration, and consciousness.

sofa.title: SOFA
sofa.description: Quantifies organ dysfunction in sepsis cases to aid in critical care decision-making.

nihss.title: NIHSS
nihss.description: Quantifies neurological deficits to evaluate stroke severity and guide treatment.

apacheii.title: Apache II
apacheii.description: Scores illness severity and predicts mortality in ICU patients based on acute physiology and chronic health data.

drug-calculators.title: Drug dosage calculators
drug-calculators.description: Use our drug dosage calculators for accurate medication dosing, tailored to patient-specific parameters.

formula-calculators.title: Formula calculator
formula-calculators.description: Employ our formula calculator to compute essential medical formulas with precision.

nerve-block.title: Peripheral nerve block
nerve-block.description: Access guidelines and protocols for performing peripheral nerve blocks with ultrasound guidance.

intubation.title: Intubation
intubation.description: Explore detailed instructions and techniques for safe and effective intubation procedures.

glasgow.name: Glasgow Coma Scale
glasgow.description: Assessment of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

four.name: FOUR Score
four.description: A coma scale used to assess patients with impaired consciousness.

result.comaIII: Coma III (extreme), death of the cerebral cortex

alertness.label: Alertness
alertness.negative5: No response to voice or physical stimulation
alertness.negative4: No response to voice, but movement to physical stimulation
alertness.negative3: Any movement (without eye contact) in response to voice
alertness.negative2: Brief awakening with eye contact (<10 seconds)
alertness.negative1: Sustained awakening with eye contact upon voice stimulation
alertness.positive2: Pulls or removes tubes/catheters or acts aggressively
alertness.positive3: Frequent non-purposeful movements or ventilator dyssynchrony
alertness.positive4: Excessively aggressive; immediate danger to personnel

alderte.name: Modified Aldrete Score
alderte.description: This scale demonstrates the patient's readiness for transfer to the ward after anesthesia.

activity.label: Activity
activity.option1: Movement in two extremities on command
activity.option2: Movement in all extremities on command

bloodPressure.label: Blood Pressure
bloodPressure.option0: 50% or more deviation from pre-anesthesia level

sofa.name: SOFA Score
sofa.description: A score for assessing the extent of organ dysfunction.

respiratory.label: PaO2/FiO2
respiratory.option3: < 200 mm Hg (26.7 kPa) with respiratory support
respiratory.option4: < 100 mm Hg (13.3 kPa) with respiratory support

cardiovascular.label: Cardiovascular (with medication doses given for ≥ 1 hour)
cardiovascular.option2: Dopamine < 5 mcg/kg/min or any dose of dobutamine
cardiovascular.option3: Dopamine 5.1–15 mcg/kg/min or epinephrine ≤ 0.1 mcg/kg/min or norepinephrine ≤ 0.1 mcg/kg/min
cardiovascular.option4: Dopamine > 15 mcg/kg/min or epinephrine > 0.1 mcg/kg/min or norepinephrine > 0.1 mcg/kg/min

nihss.name: NIH Stroke Scale
nihss.description: A standardized tool for assessing stroke severity and neurological deficits.
nihss.extraDescription: The NIH Stroke Scale is administered by sequentially evaluating 11 items. For Level of Consciousness, observe the patient’s alertness, ask two questions (e.g., 'What month is it?' and 'How old are you?'), and test simple commands (open/close eyes, grip/release hand). For Best Gaze, have the patient follow a moving object horizontally (or use oculocephalic maneuver if needed). For Visual Fields, perform a confrontation test in all quadrants and note any partial or complete field loss. For Facial Palsy, ask the patient to smile, raise eyebrows, and close eyes to check for asymmetry. For Motor responses, test each arm by having it extended (90° if sitting or 45° if supine) for 10 seconds and each leg by raising it to 30° for 5 seconds, noting any drift, decreased effort, or absence of movement. For Limb Ataxia, have the patient perform finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin tests, scoring only when incoordination exceeds weakness. For Sensory, compare responses to pinprick stimulation on both sides. For Best Language, assess the ability to describe a picture, name objects, or read sentences, scoring based on fluency and comprehension. For Dysarthria, ask the patient to repeat words to evaluate speech clarity. Finally, for Extinction and Inattention, use simultaneous stimulation to check for neglect. Record the first valid response for each item.

loc.label: Level of Consciousness
loc.option1: Not alert; arousable with minor stimulation

limbAtaxia.label: Limb Ataxia
limbAtaxia.option2: Ataxia in two or more limbs

apacheii.name: APACHE II Score
apacheii.description: A severity-of-disease classification system used to predict ICU mortality based on the worst values recorded during the first 24 hours of ICU admission.

oxygenation.label: Oxygen saturation or A–a gradient
oxygenation.option0: If FiO2 <50%: pO2 >70 mmHg; If FiO2 ≥50%: A–a gradient <200 mmHg
oxygenation.option3: If FiO2 <50%: pO2 55-60 mmHg or If FiO2 ≥50%: A–a gradient 350-499 mmHg
oxygenation.option4: If FiO2 <50%: pO2 <55 mmHg or If FiO2 ≥50%: A–a gradient >499 mmHg

apacheii.extraDescription: Note: The APACHE II Score is calculated from the worst values recorded during the first 24 hours of ICU admission. Definitions for chronic organ dysfunction and immunocompromise should follow current clinical guidelines.

calculators.alert: This calculator is for double-checking dosage and should NOT be used as the sole reference.

actilyse.label: Actilyse (Alteplase) Calculator
actilyse.annotation:
Typical total dose 0.9 mg/kg. Administer 10% as a bolus over 1 minute, then infuse the remaining 90% over 60 minutes. 

This config uses 0.9 mg/kg (bolus: 10%, infusion: 90%).

bmi.label: Body Mass Index
bmi.annotation:
BMI reference ranges are based on WHO guidelines: 
- under 18.5 (underweight) 
- 18.5–24.9 (normal) 
- 25–29.9 (overweight) 
- ≥30 (obese).

dailyCalories.label: Daily Calorie Requirements
dailyCalories.annotation: This calculation uses the Mifflin-St Jeor formula. Actual calorie needs may vary by individual.

creatinineClearance.label: Creatinine Clearance
creatinineClearance.annotation:
Uses the Cockcroft-Gault formula to estimate creatinine clearance
Stage I: Kidney damage with normal or increased GFR ≥90 mL/min/1.73 m²
Stage II: Kidney damage with mild decrease in GFR (60–89 mL/min/1.73 m²)
Stage III: Moderate decrease in GFR (30–59 mL/min/1.73 m²)
Stage IV: Severe decrease in GFR (15–29 mL/min/1.73 m²)
Stage V: Kidney failure (GFR <15 mL/min/1.73 m²)

dailyWaterBalance.label: Daily Water Balance

result.balance: Daily water balance taking into account perspiration

dailyWaterBalance.annotation: This provides a rough estimate of water balance based on intake and output. Clinical context may require adjustments.

algoverIndex.label: Algover Index
algoverIndex.annotation: Algover index helps estimate hypovolemia risk; values above 1.0 may indicate significant volume depletion.

dailyDiuresis.label: Hourly Diuresis Rate
dailyDiuresis.annotation:
The following values ​​are usually used as a guide (in ml/kg/h):
Adults: the norm is considered to be ≈0.5–1 ml/kg/h (some sources give up to 2 ml/kg/h, everything depends on specific clinical conditions).
Children: the indicator is higher and strongly depends on age (in newborns it can reach 2–3 ml/kg/h, in older children it is closer to the indicators of adults).

plasmaExchange.label: Plasma Exchange Calculator
plasmaExchange.annotation:
Formulas used in this calculator:
1. Total Blood Volume (TBV) = Weight (kg) × Coefficient, where the coefficient is 70 mL/kg for males and 65 mL/kg for females.
2. Circulating Plasma Volume (PV) = TBV × ((100 - Hematocrit) / 100).
3. Removed Plasma Volume (RPV) = PV × (Removal Percentage / 100) × Correction Factor.

The Correction Factor is fixed at 1.05 by default and adjusts the removal volume based on clinical requirements.

thiopental.label: Thiopental
thiopental.annotation:
20 mL = 1 g or 10 mL = 500 mg freeze-dried. Usually reconstituted to a 1% solution. Typical IV dose 3–6 mg/kg. Onset ≈1–2 min; duration ≈20–25 min. 

This config uses ~4.5 mg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

propofol.label: Propofol
propofol.annotation:
20 mL = 200 mg emulsion. Typical dosages: for induction 1.5–2.5 mg/kg || infusion rate 4-12.5 mg/kg/hr. Onset ≈20–40 s; duration ≈6–8 min. 

This config uses ~2 mg/kg for induction and ~5 mg/kg/h for infusion by default with the ability to customize.

ketamine.label: Ketamine
ketamine.annotation:
May be selected in hypotensive patients. 

2 mL = 100 mg. Typical IV dose 1.5–2 mg/kg. Onset ≈1–2 min IV; duration ≈15–20 min IV. 

This config uses ~1 mg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

gomh.label: Sodium Oxybutyrate
gomh.annotation:
1 mL = 200 mg. Typical dose 50–150 mg/kg IV. Onset ≈5–10 min; duration 20–60+ min. 

This config uses ~75 mg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

fentanyl.label: Fentanyl
fentanyl.annotation:
2 mL amp = 0.05 mg (50 mcg). Typical bolus 0.5–2.5 mcg/kg. Onset rapid; duration ≈10–15 min. 

This config uses ~0.5 mcg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

ditilin.label: Ditilin (Succinylcholine)
ditilin.annotation:
5 mL = 100 mg. Typical dose 0.6–1.5 mg/kg IV for rapid muscle relaxation. Onset ≈30–60 s; duration ≈5–10 min. 

This config uses ~0.75 mg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

atracurium.label: Atracurium
atracurium.annotation:
2.5 mL = 25 mg or 5 mL = 50 mg. Typical bolus 0.5–0.6 mg/kg. Onset ~3–5 min; duration ≈15–35 min. 

This config uses ~0.5 mg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

dexon.label: Dexamethasone
dexon.annotation:
1 mL = 4 mg. Typical single dose ~4–8 mg (1–2 amps) or ~0.06–0.11 mg/kg. 

This config uses ~0.08 mg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

naloxone.label: Naloxone
naloxone.annotation:
1 mL = 0.4 mg. Typical bolus ~1.5–3 mcg/kg IV. 

This config uses ~2 mcg/kg (~0.002 mg/kg) by default with the ability to customize.

noradrenaline.label: Noradrenaline (Norepinephrine)
noradrenaline.annotation:
4 mL amp = 8 mg or 8 mL amp = 16 mg. Common infusion 0.1–1 mcg/kg/min. 

This config uses ~0.4 mcg/kg/min (0.0004 mg/kg/min) by default with the ability to customize.

dopamine.label: Dopamine
dopamine.annotation:
5 mL = 200 mg or 25 mg. Starter dose range is 2-5 mcg/kg/min. Typical infusion 2–20 mcg/kg/min. 

This config uses ~2 mcg/kg/min (0.002 mg/kg/min) by default with the ability to customize.

nitroglycerin.label: Nitroglycerin
nitroglycerin.annotation:
1, 5, or 10 mg/mL vials. Often diluted to 100 mcg/mL. 

Typical infusion 0.5–10 mcg/kg/min. This config uses ~2 mcg/kg/min (0.002 mg/kg/min) by default with the ability to customize.

sufentanil.label: Sufentanil
sufentanil.annotation:
50 mcg/ml stand for 5 mL = 250 mcg. Typical range for induction is 0.05 - 0.1 mcg/kg. May be administered in divided dose. 

This config uses ~0.05 mcg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

rocuronium.label: Rocuronium
rocuronium.annotation:
5 mL = 50 mg. Typical bolus 0.6–1 mg/kg. Onset ~1–2 min; duration ~30–50 min. 

This config uses ~0.6 mg/kg by default with the ability to customize.

pediatricInfusion.label: Pediatric infusion rate
pediatricInfusion.annotation: Infusion rate (mL/h) = (weight (kg) × 60 × dose (mcg/kg/min) / (drug concentration (%) × 10000)) × total volume after dilution (mL)
